messages.text:
The following points have been completed:
- Updated parent block with child thread once the child thread is created.
- Implemented loader while authenticating with Google.

The develop branch is now ready to be merged, and a pull request has been created for the same.

Here is the PR link: <https://github.com/TranscendHQ/Monk/pull/3>

Thank you! Awesome work!
Merged successfully. :raised_hands:

We need to carefully trade-off these optimizations with SlackIntegration feature though.. I am engaging with a contractor to build AI knowledge graph on top of slack messages. We will have to prioritize slack integration.
Sure thing, this is our next top priority.

Let me know if you need any help .. one thing I liked about supertokens was that the SDK abstracts out most of the functionality. So, I could implement social login, without truly understanding how oauth works (which is kinda whole point. The reason I am outsourcing auth to supertokens is because I want to focus on building the product, and not becoming an auth expert).
here is the documentation again:

<https://supertokens.com/docs/thirdpartypasswordless/custom-ui/thirdparty-login>
<https://pub.dev/packages/flutter_appauth>
<https://wso2.com/asgardeo/docs/tutorials/auth-users-into-flutter-apps/>
<https://api.slack.com/authentication/sign-in-with-slack>

Also, I see some lag in loading the Newsfeed. I will check at the backend if we can improve the database fetch. Otherwise we can introduce some pagination as well so user sees some threads quickly while the others load.
Database fetch improvement can reduce loading time significantly but in longer term we'll need this pagination eventually.
Agreed, I'll add that loader there too.

There is one small enhancement. When the user logs in with Google, sometimes it takes a while. The user still sees 'login with google' button. May be we can show a 'signing in' message with rotating/loading kind of circle?
sure.

Currently, when a user clicks on the "Reply in thread" button, the API creates a child thread and redirects the user to reply within that thread. However, upon returning to the previous page, the same button remains as "Reply in thread" within the block. Ideally, this button should be changed to "Replies" after creating a child thread.
No worries. I'll wait. I am currently in a meeting where I have to show a small demo. I'll use the develop branch for the demo. Do the PR when you think it's best
Ok, Let me push today's code to develop. so that you can have latest code.

The issue we were experiencing yesterday has been resolved. However, there are still some finishing things remaining, such as adding child_id within the parent block once the reply thread is created. If you believe this can be addressed after merging the PR to dev, let me know I'll raise the PR.
ok to merge develop branch now?

Google Firebase documentation is bad! for the life of me, I cannot figure out what I have t do in the back end for open id auth. Let's stick to supertokens. It's already working for Google login. Open ID should be very similar.

renamed all the "id" fields in all blocks to "_id" in the database. Not sure if this will create any side effects, but we should be good for now. You should be able to create a child to any block now.
Ok, thanks

pushed the fixes:
1. Newly created blocks have the key "_id" instead of "id". We still have to fix all the old blocks in the db. For now, you can create new blocks and work with them.
2. Pushed new API to get the thread with just the thread_id as input. See example 
```await threadApi.getThreadIdThreadsIdGet(
        id: "2bcad996-8391-4ddf-a274-bf84d6904906");```

I have tested the new API to create the child thread of a block.
• You will need to provide the id of parent block, and id of parent thread while creating the child thread. 
• child_id field of Parent block is automatically updated with the child thread's id.
• Also child thread automatically gets populated with the one block (parent block's content).
• In UI, when user clicks 'reply in thread', then this api to create child should be called. It returns the child thread with it's content, which you can render.
• The parent block must now show 'replies'. Clicking on replies should simply navigate to the child thread (you already have child_id, which can be used to fetch the thread)
Here is the sample code for the API call
```    CreateChildThreadModel createChildThreadModel = CreateChildThreadModel(
      title: "myownchildthread",
      type: "/new-plan",
      parentBlockId: "b342a310-cd4e-444e-8f0f-8e511d908b7f",
      parentThreadId: "713059f7-b4ca-49ed-a35c-d28e6569da81",
    );
    await threadApi.childThreadBlocksChildPost(
        createChildThreadModel: createChildThreadModel);```
OK, I'll check this API today
<@U066Q9JAU3B> with this same `createChildThreadModel` object I am getting null response values and when I am sending other values then I am getting status code 500.
one more thing in `BlockModel` the json key if `id` is not defied as `_id`. So due to this I am not able to access the id. I have checked the API response and it is coming as `_id`.

Re: the null response. If you tried exactly the parameters that I shared (same parent block and thread ids), you will get null. The backend sends null and prints this message ("block already has a child thread")
This is to prevent to create many spurious orphaned child threads..
I just manually deleted the child thread in the database and the api worked as expected.
Now if you try it should work (because I just deleted the child again).

Here is the api response when new thread is created
``````

Using this code we can get access token using `<https://slack.com/api/openid.connect.token>` api.
Once we have `access_token` we can get the list of channels and conversations.

Ok. I see that shortcut for entering new block is Meta+Enter instead of SHIFT+ENTER. We should change the text hint accordingly.

Yes, I'll fix this today

Here is what I am thinking re; Slack integration
1. User signs in with Slack - <https://api.slack.com/authentication/sign-in-with-slack>
2. We implement a second oauth flow to ask for additional scopes for the user - <https://api.slack.com/authentication/oauth-v2>
3. We show user's public channels in the frontend UI and ask them to select the channels they want to import to Monk - <https://api.slack.com/methods/conversations.list>
4. After the import is finished, we show the channel's threads in the newfeed. - <https://api.slack.com/methods/conversations.history>
5. Optionally we could invite Monk app to all the public channels that user is a part of. But for that,  someone will have to install Monk bot - <https://api.slack.com/methods/conversations.invite>
Do you see any gotchas in this plan?

This approach seems good to me. However, I have a question regarding who will be able to import the Slack channel from Monk after logging in with Slack. Can any user do this, or is it limited to a particular role such as an admin?

THAT is a million dollar question. Only way to test this is to try it. Documentation is unclear.
In order to read messages from all public channels a user is a part of, they need the following scopes:

`channels:history`
`groups:history`
`im:history`
`mpim:history`

If (BIG IF) we are able to implement the oauth flow where user requests these scopes, and is granted a corresponding token, then we can use that token to read the channel messages.
After login with Slack, on which screen we will show Slack public channel to user for import?
the screen after loggin in, we will ask the user if they would like to import their public slack channels to Monk. If they say yes, we will request additional scope using oauth.

Below points are done and pushed to develop branch.
• Add thread detail page showing list of main thread and list of replies.
• Added thread detail provider to handle thread detail state and simulate api call.

Here is the sample JSON structure that needed in replies API response.
```{
  "thread":{
      "id": "SOME-ID",
      "content": "",
      "created_at": "",
      "created_by": "",
      "creator_email": "",
      "creator_picture": "",
      "replyCount":2
    },
  "replies": [
    {
      "parentId:"SOME-ID",
      "id": "7eeab029-fa46-4a13-aa10-ed7f60875230",
      "content": "A company with sizable number of employees (> 500) will tend to grow in all directions (personal agendas, divergent ideas, lack of clarity, lack of alignment etc.)\n",
      "created_at": "2024-03-11T00:23:53.147000",
      "created_by": "Yogesh K. Soni",
      "creator_email": "<mailto:yksoni@gmail.com|yksoni@gmail.com>",
      "creator_picture": "<https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/a/ACg8ocINw3k9RplX-1xQQbxdmKav0dxSRaJ8xsMyI-HWvtpFXlkn=s96-c>"
    },
    {
      "parentId:"SOME-ID",
      "id": "33fda9b0-3170-47c6-b593-c8d14b295313",
      "content": "A company can be thought of as a town with an economy that needs to be sustained.\nor it can be thought of as a pirate ship, that needs to look for next oppurtunity to loot.",
      "created_at": "2024-03-11T00:25:15.803000",
      "created_by": "Yogesh K. Soni",
      "creator_email": "<mailto:yksoni@gmail.com|yksoni@gmail.com>",
      "creator_picture": "<https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/a/ACg8ocINw3k9RplX-1xQQbxdmKav0dxSRaJ8xsMyI-HWvtpFXlkn=s96-c>"
    }
    
  ]
}```

I think you mean "Block" here and not "thread" in the top-level json.

Feed = Collection of Threads
Thread = Collection of Blocks
Blocks = (Sometimes), collection of replies, where reply is also a block.

If the taxonomy is starting to get complicated, we will need to simplify it. Block is simply a message. May be that is a better term. Block seems technical. Thread is a conversation. Feed is a list of conversation.

I have a suggestion which will make the design simpler.
If we are gonna show replies in a new page anyways, might as well create a new thread. Don't you think it is simpler then?

What this mean is that, we will not have to implement the concept of replies in the database and in our api.

Think about this, we are essentially forking a new conversation.

Replies is simply a pointer to a new child thread that contains blocks.

So when a user presses 'reply' button, frontend should call create new thread api with {"type":"child", title;"blockid_of_parent_block"}.

If a block has replies, then the frontend should show '<n> replies' instead

Let's discuss this further before implementing more code.

Re: sometimes id of block being null, I saw indeed corrupt blocks in the database. They were leftovers from initial days.
They look like following and I have deleted them:
Agreed with the new thread concept.
ok. Try implementing this flow, where when user presses 'reply' button, a new thread is created, with the parent blocks as the first block
Just checked `null` is not getting for all threads Id. There are some threads existswhich have this null value.
Hi, I am getting Id as `null` in all thread blocks. Apart from this fix, can you add reply count ? it is required to be displayed on the thread card.
Sure

yes, reply box will always be visible. I assume by reply box, you mean the replies, that are blocks of texts .
I didn't quite understand the second question. Quick huddle?
Regarding the replies, the reply box will always be visible for each thread right ? I am assuming thread reply content format will be the same as tread.

ok. Sounds like a plan. While I work on the backend API, you could make 2 changes in rendering the thread
1. Block with replies (from Figma Design pages 8/9)
2. Web link metadata (this solves a lot of usecases).

I think we should integrate Slack gradually, starting with fetching a list of channels with other threads list. Then, we can display the Slack channel messages in a plain text format, followed by the possibility of showing content in a rich text format later on.

Re; your question about how are Slack messages different, I see a few things:
1. Slack threads don't have titles and types. We can either generate them automatically, or use channel name as title for now and 'slack' for type.
2. Messages inside channels can have replies (threads). So the back end will give content in the following format:
       [ block, block, block_with_replies, block, block]
       So, we need to implement the block_with_replies in the frontend as well.
 3. Slack messages can have emojis, code blocks, mentions etc. Since we don't support these, we need to think how do we plan to render the content of these types.

Anything else I am missing?
Yes. As far as accessing threads from slack, we should stick to the same method for accessing them.
Right now we are accessing threads using `/go` command. Is this the same way to access slack channel ?

Alternatively below is the sample api response needed for slack channel.
```{
  "creator": {
    "name": "NAME",
    "picture": "PICTURE",
    "id": "ID"
  },
  "createdAt": "TIME",
  "type": "message",
  "ts": "1702168021.581239",
  "client_msg_id": "1e841c8e-0bb0-4182-807d-6978d796d611",
  "text": "open source model to try - mistral <<https://replicate.com/nateraw/mixtral-8x7b-32kseqlen>>",
  "attachments": [
    {

This is the slack api that I am using -> <https://api.slack.com/messaging/retrieving>

One more thing this api also returns every event data. for example messages, user joined/left channel etc. I think we need to find a way to filter only message type data.
Here is the sample date of user joined event.
```{
            "subtype": "channel_join",
            "user": "U06P1K7DANB",
            "text": "<@U06P1K7DANB> has joined the channel",
            "inviter": "U06M70HTC7Q",
            "type": "message",
            "ts": "1710393806.729219"
},```
this api returns only messages in a conversation (aka channel).. <https://api.slack.com/methods/conversations.replies>

Additionally, you could spot threads within a conversation and retrieve replies within a thread using the following method.
<https://api.slack.com/messaging/retrieving#finding_threads>

here is a piece of python code to list channels
```import os
from slack_sdk import WebClient

# Get the bot token from the environment variable
SLACK_BOT_TOKEN = os.environ.get("SLACK_BOT_TOKEN")

# Create a Slack client instance
client = WebClient(token=SLACK_BOT_TOKEN)

response = client.conversations_list()

if response["ok"]:
    # Iterate through channels and print name and ID
    for channel in response["channels"]:
        print(f"Channel Name: {channel['name']}, ID: {channel['id']}")
else:
    print(f"Error: {response['error']}")```

Ok, I will check how to get the user name and channel names.. How did you authenticate to retrieve this information from Slack API? Was being a member of public channel enough, even though you are not a slack admin? Is User token enough?
I see you added Monk Service app. What kind of authorization do you need for this?

By using another api, you could get a list of user profile info and store it.. then you could look up user's name using their Id.
<https://api.slack.com/methods/users.list/code>

similarly, you could list channels, and then figure out the channel names from a given ID.
<https://api.slack.com/methods/admin.usergroups.listChannels>
One last thing: It seems an app has to be invited to a public channel manually (or programmatically by a user who is already member of the channel). Bot cannot read messages otherwise.

That is correct. I manually added the bot to the channel and then created an app-level token for it from the Slack app dashboard. This token serves as the authentication bearer token in the API for retrieving channel history.
